transcript.content: Patrick Johnson_Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I'm serving second degree murder, life without parole. I'm currently been locked up 26 years from Tangipahoa parish. I was 18 years old when the crime committed.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and you can look at me. So, it's just, think of it as more of an informal conversation, so I'm going to start with some questions about you coming up. So you're from Tangipahoa parish.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I'm from Mississippi. I caught my charge in Tangipahoa parish.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You're from Mississippi. And did you grow up in Mississippi?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I grew up in Mississippi.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Where in Mississippi?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: McComb.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so tell me a little bit about your family, about the folks who raised you.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I was raised by my mother and my grandmother. My father was pretty much in my life until I grew up some. My grandmother was a loving caring person that took us in and shared, fed us, clothed us, made sure we had the best days and kept us in school and provided for us and my mother was to my grandmother is my mother.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: My mother is like a sister because we was so close apart. My mother had me when she was 16 and she became 30 when I was 16 well we were like sisters and brothers because we were so close. Time carried on, my grandmother passed away and for the first time ever, I called my mother "Mom."

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so "Momma" was what you called your grandma. Everybody called her that. So you have siblings?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: No sir.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I probably have no kids I just helped raised my niece and nephew from here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and you don't have any brothers or sisters.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I have brothers and sisters.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh yeah tell me about your siblings.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I have 4 brothers and I have three sisters. My mother had 4 boys and my daddy which I found out by my mother's sisters later on that he has three sisters. All of them cared. They caring people. They have kids. They care about their kids. They care of me, they come see me, and they love me. And I grew up with my brothers and them until I departed from being incarcerated. I met my sisters and them during the time of incarceration.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: From your dad's with a different mom. So, the boys. Tell me about them. Where are you in the birth order? Are you the oldest?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Next to oldest. My brother over my, Kevin, is the oldest. I'm under him. Jeffery's under me and Brandon is the youngest.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So how old was your mother when she had Jeffery?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: She was 38 so she had to be about 22.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I'm sorry who's the oldest brother?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Kevin is the oldest.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old was your mother when Kevin was.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: She was 14.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay wow. So she was very young very young mother. What about school?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I went to Old Sike Elementary that was a small one here come I went to South Pike High School where I completed the 12th grade. I didn't have a chance to graduate because I was going back and forth in court. And so during that time, I never finished graduate.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so eleventh grade was your last. Okay, since you've been in prison, we're going to talk about that. Have you gone ahead and get your GED?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I got my GED, my education, I've been in so many self-help programs and educational programs, they better my education.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I'm gathering that if there was one person that was very special in your life who took an interest in you coming up it would be your grandmother. So you told me that she passed away do you remember were you here at Angola?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I was here at Angola.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember your last interaction with her?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Yes I do.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about that.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I wrote about it like it was yesterday. Her birthday is April 22nd. And in 2001, she had her legs amputated because diabetic but through all the excruciating pain and stuff, she was able to come visit, which I never knew I was getting a visit from her, but they called me for a visit and I'm like "wow, who do I get a visit?" I see my grandmother and I said "Man I knew you were in some kind of pain"

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: She said she wanted to be there to see me because she didn't have a long time left. So right then I knew that her time was coming to an end because she wanted to see me so bad. And they granted her a visit. They granted it for her and all. That was the last time that we really had intimate conversation.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Do your siblings still come up and visit you now?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Yes they do.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do they come to the rodeo?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: All of them.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All of them come to the rodeo.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: My birthday sometimes. They open up the rodeo October 7th and they open up the rodeo again this year, and everybody will come.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I see kind of a reunion.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Like a reunion.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That must be really nice. Do you sell things in?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Hobby craft. I worked the Ferris wheel. I worked the Ferris wheel kids and sell my hobby craft by the Ferris wheel.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay what do you make?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Belts, purses, teddy bears, wallets.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you grew up in Mississippi in McComb. Can you paint a picture for me? If we are at your house at your front door when you are 17, 18 years old. What would I see if I was standing there?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: My neighborhood as I was standing there when I left the current in the apartment that we stayed at was called. You'll see streets, ball parks, and a lot of people, in a small community.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so fairly nicely populated area?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: It's populated.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay was it public housing?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Public housing.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay public housing, okay. People getting in trouble, fighting?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Yeah poverty. It wasn't really private, in just that like a low income acorn/McComb? Housing apartments and drugs, pretty much gang activity, stuff like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright. Did you find it hard to stay out of trouble, living in that environment?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Yes. I was pretty much a high school. I pretty much was getting angry at a lot of people. I pretty much stayed home and worked and just family things because I had to try to provide for my mother because like I said, we didn't have a father. We built and stuff. So I was school and partially working.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and where were you working?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I worked at State Park and my coach got me on a job to help make money to go to school because speaking about, my coaches in school pretty much took me in to help me provide a way for.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. So is there a particular coach that you think of when you tell me about that?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I have to say Mr. Swanger and if I have to say just one but it's really all my coaches.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And these are football coaches?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: These are football coach. And he was my mentor, he took me in, took care of me and motivated me, showed me what a father. I never had like I said, my father wasn't in my life and he showed me that this is what you've got to do to become a man and gave me guidelines. He pretty much motivated me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. So that's you're kind of lucky to have somebody like that come into your life, take an interest in you. He must have recognized something in you.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Well, when I was it was 5th grade, I was kicked out of school. It was Old Sike Elementary and I was mowing the yard and there's people passing by, coaches. Mr. Swanger and passed by they would see me like "Why you not in school? You got potential. Nice kid." And one day, they just pulled over and stopped. So I told them I was expelled from school for fighting, pushing and I got expelled.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: They went and looked into the matter. I shouldn't have gotten expelled but I was so they gave me another shot and I would walk to practice because my mother couldn't have the chance to carry me to practice all the time on her jobs. I would walk 5 or 6 miles to school to practice. People would see this and say I was so dedicated that that's how my life began on the streets.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. And I assume you played football in high school. Okay. Was there any was there a lot of fighting in your home?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Not very much.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay but in the neighborhood.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: In the neighborhood, lots.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright, any did you have any abuse in your history?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Not really like I said, my mother raised us and we never really had any home abuse in our house. Everybody pretty much was raised in the house there really was no kind of abuse.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. Were there men who came into your mother's life who then came into your life and created some conflict?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Well, I can go back and say that. My mother met a freighter/friend guy and the way they broke up was a very big argument and I got in between them but I wouldn't say that was abuse because one time that it happened. I was protecting my mother being the man of the house, going my older brother, he was there too but I was a little bigger. I got in between them. He pushed I really don't look at it as abuse, just something that happened.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Sure and was that the only incident?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: That I can recall.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, okay. So you were kicked out of school for fighting. Your coaches take an interest in you, you get back, now you got football. Did you have any other run-ins with the law?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Never.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, when you're 18, and you got picked up on this charge, that was your first arrest?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: That was my first arrest. Never had been in a police car. Never been questioned by the police.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow. Alright, well, what about girlfriends?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Plenty Gabrielle was my most intimate girlfriend. I felt like forever we been together forever and the day that I caught my charge, I was on my way to see her and everybody was calling her like "Hey have you seen him?" And everyone found out what had happened and they were like, "Have you seen him, have you seen him? We've been looking for him."

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: She was like "Oh my God, I got to find him but I was trying to find my way to my mother to let her know what had happened. And during the time that we was passing by everybody, she came and found me just my luck. I didn't want to say "Sweet heart, my love"

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And you said earlier that to me that you don't have any kids. Okay. Do you still have a relationship with her?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Well, time go on been locked up 25 years, 26 years, people move on. I never was upset she come visit me twice because I had been incarcerated and we had been life because sometimes it can hurt another person and you don't want to hold anybody back so you want to let go. So we decided that it would be the best.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, that makes sense. So you're just friends.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Just friends.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. So she's the one that stands out in your mind. Do you have anybody else who visits you other than family?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Wait I'm involved in so much stuff here that I could sit even when I'm outside, people come around me just visiting and we are sociable, but I take care of so many events with the kids with Returning Hearts when people come down, I've known so many of them for years.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: It's felt like visits too. I have others that my best friend Frasier her and her husband, Todd, they come visit me. She graduated from the same school. She really was trying to help me get out of prison also. She can't after 25 years. And they've been my friends for a long time.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So what brought you to Tangipahoa parish from home?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: My dad, when I ran into my dad, I ran into my dad when he was incarcerated at Tangipahoa parish jail. One day I was at a store in Kentwood and a lady said "You look just like my brother." And I'm like "My daddy name is Delois Gatler and she said "That's my brother." And from that day on, I met the other side of my family. And they stay in Kentwood Louisiana which is Tangipahoa parish.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right, now but what brought you there in the first place?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: They got a place called Bamboo that we liked to eat at. It's in Kentwood. I wanted Bamboo and that's why and that let me to come back and forth from family to family, learning my family in Louisiana and Mississippi.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Got it. Makes sense. So can you very briefly explain what got you here, the charge that got you here?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: One day, my baby brother's birthday was on August the 6th. The day it happened. I was going to drive to Wacom/McComb in my car, quick, so I just up, I walked to the bar room, to get some friends to my girlfriend's house, and I got to the club. They said they'd be back in a few minutes and they told me to chill.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: When they come back, they'll pick me up and give me the ride, so I stayed and I chilled. My cousin came to the club which, previous weeks, he went with my older brother. Saw me at the club, I asked him for 25 cent and it sparked a whole argument. And the argument led to this, led to that. He left, come back, we got into it and yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright and if you had to identify, one cause because now your whole life is now defined by that right? By that change. Was it just an impulsive out of emotion? What was going on? What happened? I guess, why did it happen?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I think one of the reasons. I go back to the day like I can revisit that day I hate doing it, but I can revisit that day and the sudden passion as I learned, is just a heated spur of the moment thing that changed everything forever. It should have never happened but it did and you can't go back and save that change it because you can't too much time has passed from it. It happened. Shouldn't have happened. I regret it happening.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And you're 18. I mean, you're a kid and you're impulsive. Now when you look back in it, I'm sure because, what you were doing. I understand but at the time it's what happened. So were drugs and alcohol part of your life?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright. Well let me ask you this. I'm sure that many times, you've asked an if question like what if this hadn't happened. What if you didn't get out of bed that day for example? So, how do you think the next few months and years of your life would have gone? How do you imagine it would have been had this not happened?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I feel if this wouldn't have happened, I probably would have graduated from high school and lived out my dream of playing football at the university collegiate and professionally and like you can never really say what happens, we never can predict what's going to happen.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right, but that's kind of. That's the path.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: To be a productive person and be able to give to the neighborhoods and to give back.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I'm going to switch gears and start talking a little bit about your time after that. But before I move to Angola, I guess it was the Parish for a little bit and then Angola but before we go there, is there something else I should have asked you about your childhood that's important to who you are today? Anything I should have asked you?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: My demeanor from then to now is I would look humbled. And I guess when you get incarcerated, something happens. A lot of things change transformation change. And you got to become another person. Because during that time, coming to prison was you heard all the bad things. You had to decide to either be this person, that person and it I was a humbled person.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. You had to change that in order to survive prison. Right. So tell me about that. Do you remember your bus ride over here?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I remember my bus ride was the longest ride in history. Feel like forever. I was in Hunts waiting for transition to here. I stayed about two week and all I heard was the stories of "they going to LSP. Already knew where he was going or man they kill, they do this, they rape, do all kinds of stuff, man, you got to live like this, you got to do this."

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I heard so many stories. So now, I knew then, I had to put it inside me that well, it's either kill or be killed. I'm going to live a certain way to gain respect. That's what it was about what I heard. So the long ride from Hunts to hear it like took forever. We arrived at the gates. Everybody was talking.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: The miles rows 20 miles come to Angola, you could hear a pin drop. Now I see that everybody had their fear. Because at first I was like "well, I'm not going to be scared." When I turned down that 20 mile stretch road, I felt the fear and it was like it kept going. It kept going. And I felt when I got to Angola, when I got to that front gate, I was drenched in sweat, like man, wow.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: This is surreal and sure enough, when I walked through RC and they told me I was going through the yard because they liked guys, they like "You can take care of yourself, you going to the yard." I'm like "What's the yard?" And "You are going to where all the worst criminals at." I'm like "Wow" and that walk down the walk was like "man, could I make it down? I'm going to lock myself up and I'm going to stay in lock down somewhere behind bars"

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: But I took the walk and I went inside Pine 3, the first dormitory I ever stepped in and it was 2:30 at night and I walked in the dormitory with 64 other guys and I made the bed, one bed. I made 64 so I was like wow. And it was like man I couldn't really breathe and I'm like scared and I didn't sleep the first night. And I was up all day. It was a long process. And I couldn't sleep so next matter of fact, they called breakfast that morning, the guy said "Man, there's breakfast. Do you want to go eat?"

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I'm like "No, I'm good." So I wouldn't even go to chow. I wouldn't do nothing for the first days until I really figured out what was going on. I was really just paranoid. I was frightened from all the stuff that I heard but I couldn't now I'd seen a few guys that I'd met at home previously. So I kind of really cooled calmed down some.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. So were some of those stories true?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Well, I guess a lot of its true because the first day, my first day here at Angola, I witnessed a guy get hit in the head and blow like literally everywhere. And I'm like "Wow, this is actually going on every day" Of course for that week, it went on for days, nights and stuff like that so I'm like "Wow, I see now. I got to prepare myself for anything. There was worse to come." But as time went on, it wasn't really like that. It's what you do when you get here, now I do everything is about respect. But, it was bad.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Then did they send you to go out and work in the field?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I worked out in the field. The first time you get it, the first month, you're going to go out in half and the first time I went in the field, the man just told me to leave because they have enough guys so they only take out so many people, they'll leave you in, so you might go around the building, pick up stuff, by my being young just getting here, they really do that.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I found out they were still on the compound, the best day to do is stay on the field. Staying on the compound might get you into more trouble than you think. Being around, seeing other people do other stuff all day long and you get caught in this kind of time doing stuff, bad habits, so going in the field was a way to stay out of trouble, a way you would learn to motivate yourself to be a better person.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, it's an interesting thing when there I spoke with somebody who was very interesting to me. He said that you have to become a different person to survive in prison and then he had to rehabilitate himself from that person as part of his whole transformation. Is that kind of accurate for you?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: It's accurate because it's true. To come into prison at a young age, you've got to transform. You got to get no you not going to be the perfect person. Because it's going to be some bumps and bruises along the way. It's going to be on you to determine yourself to stay that way. You got to change. If I would to stay in the same mindset I was when I first came to Angola, I probably never got chose for anything because I'd probably still be caught up in all the crazy stuff in prison.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: And it took me a few years to really adjust because at the field guards change, and before get people to really like cause problems in the field, I would like when you're done, I'd be like "I'm not doing no work. I'm not working no more." And I fell into the seeing other prisoners doing this to avoid work. At a certain point in time that if you going in the dungeon, you get ten days isolation.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: You stay ten days. That's ten days no work, I'm doing nothing. So I learned that when the holidays come, you get a lot of weeks off. So I made a pattern of getting locked up so I wouldn't do no work in the field. And I learned just by watching patterns of other inmates following patterns but later on down the line, I knew that would hurt me or hinder me that things would change.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right, sure, sure. Well, obviously one of the reasons that we're interested in talking with you is that you are widely considered to be a rehabilitated person who's trusted in the community. You're a trustee and quite different from the 19 year old, 18 year old that was brought here. If you could go back and give that 19 year old I'm assuming you're 19 right? A little bit of time in the parish to coming in here?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I came at age 22.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: At 22. Even longer. So if you could go back to that 22 year old, Patrick, what would you tell him? What advice would you give him?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: That you don't have to be nobody but yourself and anything that you do in life, it reflects on you. And be what you want to be. The person inside you, be yourself.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How long did it take you to figure that out?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Man. I think it took me all the way until I came to Angola in '96. It took me to figure it out, 10 years. 10 years because I was in the cell in extended lockdown $$ I'll never forget this. It was raining, snowing outside. It was read bad storm. I was laying in the cell like "man does anybody love me?" This day I really wanted to give up or whatever.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: So it's a lot of time that people don't say about breaking points. But believe me, every man got a breaking point. At certain times, you were like how much more can I take? So sitting in cells all that time like it hurt my family because they can't see me physically. They going to see me behind a screen and stuff. That really hurt me. It hurt them so I was like "Wow, can I just end this right here and just let it be?"

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: But during them times, during that time of me thinking about that, the hit on my bars and said "Hey, you got a visit." "A visit? No one can visit me, there's a storm come up here. There's a storm with bad weather, ain't going to happen." But this particular day when I was going through a bad I was really having a bad time, my mother and my aunt came and I feel like it was an act of God because I was at my lowest point and they visit me and she be like "Man don't be feeling bad that we wanted to come out and see you and share our time with you."

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: That showed me that "man, they love me" So if you don't love yourself, you ain't going to never make it so that really gave me my change.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow, yeah. And then you realized that if you want to see them, you got to get out of the cell.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: Yeah, and that day since was in trouble. That same day, we was visiting, we could visit in behind the screen, the man felt so compelled by what they did, he pulled the chair outside and let us visit inside so it was like that was a change because this man was so mean and so always hollering and stuff but this man had a heart and he had seen what had happened and he said "Man, I can see that your family came in this bad weather and their sick."

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: That you can visit mine and so he gave us the time to and even though after that, I made a few little runs in, bumps in, I was really clearing myself up. And every day from that point on just changed and I never went back to that old person. Everything else has been like it's up here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. It's interesting what you just said about every person has their breaking point. It seems that when you reach that point, it can either go down or you figure out a way to survive through it right? And do you see a lot of folks who reach that breaking point and just go down?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I have seen plenty of people, friends and people who become ill or whatever that, they can't press their way through it. And a lot of older guys that when I came in, used to mentor to tell me to do the right thing, these guys I see now, their done broke. The time has broken them and they gave up.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: They lose hope, they lose focus on everything that's here and I try to go back and try to pull them to where they used to talk to me. I'm a mentor to some of them it's hard, sadly, but it's true that like I said earlier about a breaking point. You have one. Each man have one.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So that was a little bit about your life when you first came here. What's your typical day like now for you? What's your routine?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: My routine now that I go back and try teaching younger guys that come in for the shorter times the re-entry guys. I talk to a lot of those guys and I talk to a lot of people like people come in on the tours I talk to a lot of people. I try to show them that this is not known what you think that it do its prison. You even if they got another chance, I'm not mad or it don't hurt me that they got another chance to go back outside because they so sharp and I got to tell to man, do the right thing.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: But I feel like it's pivotal to tell them that but they need to stay out. Prison's not a place for nobody. Unless it's where you need to be, but no. I try to steal something and show them that I was once you. I was a person who was young and had everything and I never got a second chance like that, but I'm showing them that it's not there's a better way.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah do you work officially with the reentry program here?

transcript.speaker: Patrick
transcript.content: I'm not officially with them. It teach CPR, so we got to teach them and like I said, a lot of guys just come to CPR class or I facilitate CPR and I facilitate Malachi dads I got to deal with each one of them, but I'm on the unit where they're located so. I get to mentor with them by day.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, sure. So Malachi dads is a lot more than dads. It's also a whole life skills.

transcript.speaker: Patrick
